newsitem.title: USA: Clinton visits Ohio, seeking to tighten grip on Midwest.
newsitem.headline: Clinton visits Ohio, seeking to tighten grip on Midwest.

text.p: One week till Election Day, President Bill Clinton sought to tighten his grip on the industrial heartland on Tuesday by visiting the crucial swing state of Ohio.

Bringing a message of higher school standards to a rally at Ohio State University, Clinton also sent a signal that despite his commanding lead in opinion polls he has no intention of neglecting the pivotal states of the Midwest.

Speaking to several thousand students at the university's basketball arena, which was only half full, Clinton outlined ideas to raise standards in public schools. About a dozen supporters of Republican candidate Bob Dole interrupted the rally, shouting "Dole-Kemp" and "Tell the truth," a disruption that Clinton turned into an opportunity to flaunt his confidence and criticise his opponent.

"I bet you they won't be doing that a week from today," he said, prompting laughter and cheers. "They must not have any student loans -- Senator Dole voted against the aid to student loan programme," he added.

"We are not afraid of honest discussion and debate, so we don't have to shout our opponents down. But I might be screaming if I had that kind of record, either that or running for a rock to hide behind."
Clinton offered several modest proposals to improve education, all at little or no cost to the federal government:
-- Urging states to issue "report cards" on public schools so parents can better judge their performance.
-- Calling on states to have clear, tough standards on promoting students from one grade to the next.
-- Encouraging the creation of more "charter schools," which are run by parents and teachers.
"The only way to get excellent education for everyone is to define it, to respect it, to demand it and then to measure it," Clinton said. "We have to have high expectations."

All national opinion polls show Clinton holds an imposing lead over Dole one week before the Nov. 5 election. As a result, the president has had the luxury of campaigning recently in states that are not necessarily Democratic and of "leaning away" from parts of the country where his support is strong, aides said.
But in Ohio, Clinton was courting a state where elections are often won and lost. "Ohio is a state that you never lean away from," remarked one of his top political advisers.
Clinton currently has a 14 percentage point lead according to the latest Cincinnati Enquirer poll of the state, which has 21 of the 270 electoral votes needed to win the election.

The president was to visit Pennsylvania, another swing state, in the afternoon, making a brief stop in Philadelphia before returning to Washington in the evening. On Wednesday he leaves for his final campaign blitz, culminating on election night in Little Rock, Arkansas.
